description: From Hindi शाल (śāl) and Urdu شال‎ (śāl), from Persian شال‎ (šâl).

entries.meaning: A square or rectangular piece of cloth worn as a covering for the head, neck, and shoulders, typically by women. [from 1662]
examples: She wears her shawl when it's cold outside.

entries.meaning: A fold of wrinkled flesh under the lips and neck of a bloodhound, used in scenting.

verbs.description: shawl (third-person singular simple present shawls, present participle shawling, simple past and past participle shawled)
